title: Namandeep kaur Sauja
text:
I am a dedicated student at Monash University, currently pursuing a Master of Business Analytics, , building on a strong academic foundation with a Bachelor’s in Commerce from DAVV, India. Along with my academic journey, I have experience working as a teacher, where I organized and managed a number of school events, which helped me develop strong leadership and project management skills.
I am proficient in tools like Python, SQL, and GitHub, enabling me to transform raw data into actionable insights. I am passionate about applying these skills in the business world and aim to work in data consulting or business intelligence.

title: Exploring Haunted Places in the United States: A Data-Driven Analysis
text: Have you ever look at certain states in America and think to yourself, why do these states have more ghosts legends? This blog post looks at the haunted places across the United States and uses data to provide answers to those interested in paranormal activities. When considering over 11 thousand haunted places, we will determine which states are the most scary, and which kind of places are scarier most often. Apart from the purpose of the guide for paranormal tourists, this research can also provides the understanding about cultural and historical values.

title: Exploring Haunted Places in the United States: A Data-Driven Analysis
text:
Problem Discription
The purpose of this study is to understand the trend of the haunted place across the United States with regard to the location, category, and relation with historical events. Identifying which states are the most active and which types of geographic regions take a majority of the activity can help to establish a connection to history.

title: Exploring Haunted Places in the United States: A Data-Driven Analysis
text:
Data Description
The data set, from TidyTuesday, has about 11,000 rows. Each row has details like where the spooky place is (city, state, and map points), a brief of the site, and type (e.g., inn, graveyard). The main bits for this study are:


City: The town where it is found.
State: The U.S. state of the spooky spot.
Description: A short text box telling what the site is like.
Coordinates: Long and lat points to put the places on a map.

title: Exploring Haunted Places in the United States: A Data-Driven Analysis
text:
Analysis

location_counts <- haunted_places %>%
  group_by(location, state) %>%
  summarise(count = n(), .groups = "drop") %>%
  arrange(desc(count)) %>%
  head(5)

location_counts |>
  kable() |>
  kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover", "condensed"))



Table 1: Top five haunted locations







location
state
count

Table 1

ggplot(location_counts, aes(x = state, y = count, fill = location)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", position = "dodge") +
  theme_minimal() +
  scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Blues") +  
  labs(title = "Number of Haunted Places by State and Type",
       x = "State",
       y = "Number of Haunted Places",
       fill = "Location Type") +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))

title: Exploring Haunted Places in the United States: A Data-Driven Analysis
text:
Introduction
Have you ever look at certain states in America and think to yourself, why do these states have more ghosts legends? This blog post looks at the haunted places across the United States and uses data to provide answers to those interested in paranormal activities. When considering over 11 thousand haunted places, we will determine which states are the most scary, and which kind of places are scarier most often. Apart from the purpose of the guide for paranormal tourists, this research can also provides the understanding about cultural and historical values.

title: Exploring Haunted Places in the United States: A Data-Driven Analysis
text:
Problem Discription
Some of them are historical sites, battlefields, cemeteries or formerly conceived homes of notorious murderers that are all believed to be haunted. However, the question remains: Which states are actually more paranormal than others? What types of locations are said to be most frequently haunted? We posed two research questions: ‘What is the between historical event and haunting?’, and ‘What historical events are associated with haunted locations?’ Using a sample of almost 11,000 self-reported haunted locations from across the United States, we sought to answer these questions and explore the relationship between historical events and hauntings.

title: Exploring Haunted Places in the United States: A Data-Driven Analysis
text:
Data Description
The data set was sourced from TidyTuesday, has about 11,000 rows. Each row has details like where the spooky place is (city, state, and map points), a brief of the site, and type (e.g., inn, graveyard). The main bits for this study are:

City: The town where it is found.
State: The U.S. state of the spooky spot.
Description: A short text box telling what the site is like.
Coordinates: Long and lat points to put the places on a map.

The dataset provided by TidyTuesday was already cleaned to a large extent, minimizing the need for extensive data wrangling.
